column1: Link	Title	Text
0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN11V0MO	For some Democrats
column2: it's voting for Clinton - and keeping it quiet	"

column1: By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK One would expect voters from the heavily Democratic Brooklyn neighborhood of Cobble Hill to pick presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 general election. Just don't expect them to advertise it.Like lawns and windowsills in liberal pockets across the country
column2: much of the neighborhood is bereft of pro-Clinton signage in the final weeks before the election. It's a stark contrast to the 2012 and 2008 campaigns
column3: when President Barack Obama whipped up a frenzy of support from Democrats and his signature ""Hope"" and ""Forward"" signs were ubiquitous. The scarcity of lawn and window signs is an indication of the Democratic nominee's struggle to generate enthusiasm among left-leaning voters
column4: a challenge that's borne out in polling data
column5: and could potentially haunt her if voters fail to turn out on election day.Clinton leads Republican challenger Donald Trump by four percentage points among likely voters
column6: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released Friday. But Americans of all political stripes have been more critical of Clinton than they were of Obama when he was running for his second term four years ago
column7: according to the daily tracking poll. Among Democrats
column8: 78 percent say they have a favorable view of Clinton
column9: lower than the 89 percent favorability rating Obama had at this point in the race in 2012. Clinton's favorability drops to 28 percent among independents versus Obama's 47 percent.Nancy Kimmel Viola
column10: a 63-year-old social worker who lives about a mile away from Clinton's campaign headquarters in Brooklyn
column11: keeps a ""Bernie 2016"" sticker taped to the front door of her Carroll Gardens home
column12: a vestige of her support for the unsuccessful bid of Sen. Bernie Sanders. While she plans to vote for Clinton
column13: she confesses that her ""heart's not in it.""""I have to vote for her."" Viola said. ""Having Trump in there is too scary.""

column1: In Denver
column2: residents in the Democratic stronghold of Park Hill posted many yard signs over a local zoning issue
column3: but few for the presidential race.""Most of us around here will vote Democratic
column4: we always do
column5: but we're not overly enthusiastic for Clinton
column6: said resident Pablo Marron. ""But we are united in our opposition to Trump.""'HOLD YOUR NOSE'

column1: In the heavily Democratic Denver suburb of Northglenn
column2: banners for local office-seekers littered a major roadway
column3: but there were no accompanying Clinton signs. In the affluent liberal Washington DC suburb of Chevy Chase
column4: Maryland
column5: signs for the Democratic nominee appeared only roughly once every 10 blocks.

column1: The lack of enthusiasm isn't just hitting the Clinton campaign. Americans from both major parties say they are generally less interested in voting this year than they were in 2012
column2: according to the Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll
column3: which compared results gathered during the first 20 days of September with the same period of 2012.The Clinton campaign did not respond to emailed requests for comment.Clinton's online store displayed roughly a dozen different signs and banners for sale
column4: ranging from an 11-inch by 17-inch sign
column5: sold at $10 for a pack of two
column6: to a four-foot by six-foot ""Hillary for America"" banner
column7: which retailed for $100.Sales data was not immediately available and a request for comment from the store went unanswered.

column1: For some
column2: there is a ""hold your nose quality"" to this election
column3: said Matthew Dallek
column4: associate professor at George Washington University's Graduate School of Political Management.""The lack of signage"" in liberal enclaves may indicate
column5: Dallek said
column6: ""that there just isn't this sort of enthusiasm that existed for Obama.""But there are some blocks that buck the trend.On a street in Gowanus
column8: no fewer than four homes bore pro-Clinton signage
column9: including a life-size cutout of the Democratic nominee
column10: which rests in the windowsill of retired lawyer Chris Morrison's home. The beaming cardboard Clinton prompts many passersby to take pictures
column12: a staunch Clinton supporter.""You don't see as much signage this time around. In this neighborhood I don't get so concerned (because everyone is) more or less on the same page
column14: 66.""I worry when I go to some other places."" (Reporting By Amy Tennery in New York
column15: additional reporting by Keith Coffman in Colorado
column17: D.C. and Chris Kahn in New York; Editing by Mary Milliken)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-flowers-idUSKCN11V0LC	Gennifer Flowers won't attend U.S. presidential debate: Pence	"
WASHINGTON Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence said on Sunday that Gennifer Flowers
column2: who had an affair with Bill Clinton before his 1992 presidential run
column3: will not attend Monday night's U.S. presidential debate.Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Twitter on Saturday that he was considering inviting Flowers to attend after Hillary Clinton's campaign had invited Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban
column4: one of Trump's most vociferous critics.""Gennifer Flowers will not be attending the debate tomorrow night
column5: Pence told Fox News Sunday with Chris Wallace.

column1: Donald Trump was using the tweet yesterday really to mock an effort by Hillary Clinton and her campaign to really distract attention from what the American people are going to be focused tomorrow night
column2: which is on the issues
column3: on the choice that we face
column4: Pence said.

column1: (Reporting By David Lawder; Editing by Andrea Ricci)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-kerry-idUSKCN11V0FZ	Kerry's ceaseless diplomacy faces sternest test on Syria	"
By Lesley Wroughton
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK John Kerry had heard enough.After last week's bombing of a U.N. aid convoy in Syria dealt a death blow to a ceasefire deal in which he had invested all his diplomatic capital with Russia
column2: the U.S. Secretary of State tossed aside a page of notes and looked at Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov across the horseshoe-shaped table in the U.N. Security Council.""I listened to my colleague from Russia
column3: and I sort of felt a little bit like they're sort of in a parallel universe here
column4: said a visibly angry Kerry
column5: effectively calling Lavrov a liar for blaming the United States for spoiling the ceasefire.The moment in some ways captured the former politician's time as the top U.S. diplomat
column6: which will end with a new administration in January.Not for the first time
column7: Kerry had invested months of intensive diplomacy and tireless traveling on an issue only to end up feeling let down or deceived by negotiating partners. On Syria
column8: Kerry has wanted greater U.S. involvement than President Barack Obama was willing to support.In an interview on Friday with Reuters
column9: Kerry said Lavrov's ""blatant obfuscation of reality ... took my breath away.""The attempted Syria ceasefire was his most ambitious effort to fix what some argue was the biggest foreign policy misstep of Obama's administration
column10: which began with the failure in 2013 to follow through on a ""red line"" threat against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad over the use of chemical weapons.Kerry hammered out the truce two weeks ago
column11: but was left pleading in vain with Russia last week to halt renewed air strikes on the besieged city of Aleppo. James Dobbins
column12: a former U.S. special envoy to Afghanistan
column14: ceaseless engagement"" even when pursuing administration policies he didn't always agree with.""Kerry to his credit has stayed in the game even when he had a weak hand
column16: a career diplomat who worked alongside Kerry in 2013 to hammer out a deal with President Hamid Karzai to keep U.S. forces in Afghanistan. ""The situation in Syria is too serious and too consequential to simply back off and leave it to others."" From Kerry's perspective
column17: it is better to fail than not to have tried.

column1: The weakest hand of all would be to have another round of migrants going into Europe
column2: (Russian President Vladimir) Putin do whatever he wants by dropping bombs and the United States doing nothing but pretending we're sending some support to people
column3: Kerry told Reuters.""That is the weakest hand
column4: and it is far stronger to stand up and find a way to leverage getting to the table and getting some kind of an understanding
column5: he added.TAKING RISKS

column1: In his nearly four years as America's top diplomat
column2: Kerry has racked up more miles than any other secretary of state
column3: sometimes appearing to rush in without a clear strategy.""It is clear that Kerry is prepared to take greater risks with his own personal reputation than others might have ... because they did not want to be identified with failure
column4: said Dobbins.    But some critics say Kerry stayed in the game too long in negotiating with Russia
column5: which they argue manipulated his quest for a deal over Syria to strengthen its position.

column1: The Syrian conflict
column2: with its shifting geopolitical forces
column3: complex new alliances and new threats such as the rise of Islamic State
column4: has tested Kerry like no other issue.After Obama declined to carry out threatened attacks on Assad's forces over chemical weapons
column5: Kerry perceived an opening to work with Lavrov on an agreement to get Syria to turn over its chemical arsenal
column6: he told Reuters.That deal struck in 2013 was considered a success
column7: but the war has since deteriorated and grown more complex following Russia's military intervention backing Assad last year.Now the continuing ceasefire push by Kerry strikes some as hopeless gesturing.""Kerry's plan is to do more of the same despite the repeated failure of U.S. attempts to strike a deal with Russia
column8: said Mutasem Alsyofi of the Syrian Civil Society Declaration Initiative
column9: who met Kerry in New York last week.

column1: OVERREACHING?
It's not the first time Kerry's been accused of overreaching. At the start of his term in 2013
column2: Kerry vigorously pursued a peace deal between the Israelis and Palestinians. Even as others warned of failure
column3: an undaunted Kerry spent months shuttling between Jerusalem and Ramallah.However
column4: U.S. ally Israel's announcement of 700 new housing units for Jewish settlements in territory the Palestinians claim for a future state finally caused the talks to collapse
column5: although Israel blamed the Palestinians move to apply to join 15 international conventions and treaties.Kerry's biggest accomplishments came in 2015 with the Iran nuclear deal and the U.N. climate change agreement. In both instances
column6: he had Obama's leadership and full support for the very visible U.S. role
column7: though both deals have been vilified domestically in the polarized American political environment.Last week's failure of a second Syrian ceasefire agreement brokered by Kerry unleashed a fresh round of stinging criticism of the administration's Syria policy.Republican Senator John McCain called Kerry ""intrepid but delusional"" for placing too much faith in the prospect of cooperation with Russia.Kerry
column8: a Vietnam veteran who lost to George W. Bush in the 2004 presidential election
column9: is not running for office again and has often remarked that he has nothing to lose.""In this business of diplomacy
column10: you have to test things sometimes
column11: he told Reuters. ""It is a mistake to delude yourself. It is also a mistake to avoid putting something to test where there is a reasonable chance something may be able to happen.""Hours after the tense exchange at the U.N. Security Council
column12: Lavrov and Kerry met again. The Russian diplomat had brought a new proposal for putting the ceasefire back on track. Kerry looked at the sheet of paper
column13: folded it tightly and stuffed it into his top pocket. (Additional reporting by Phil Stewart
column14: Patricia Zengerle in Washington; editing by Stuart Grudgings)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-netanyahu-idUSKCN11U0PK	Netanyahu to meet Clinton and Trump during U.S. visit: sources	"
JERUSALEM Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
column2: who is currently visiting the United States
column3: will separately meet U.S. presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump on Sunday
column4: campaign sources and Israeli officials said.The meetings will take place a day before Clinton and Trump face off in a first presidential debate but no details of where or when the meetings will take place were immediately available.Netanyahu traveled to the United States this week to address the U.N. General Assembly and met U.S. President Barack Obama and a number of other world leaders.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: Clinton met Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi
column3: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe who also addressed the U.N. General Assembly. Trump also met Sisi.

column1: (Additional reporting by Emily Flitter in New York
column2: Writing by Ori Lewis; Editing by Alison Williams)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN11U0PG	Clinton server tech told FBI of colleagues' worries about system	"
By Jonathan Allen
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK A technician hired by Hillary Clinton to run the private email system she used while U.S. secretary of state told investigators he tried to pass on colleagues' concerns that the system might not comply with records laws
column2: FBI interview summaries show. Bryan Pagliano
column3: the technician Clinton hired when she joined the State Department in 2009
column4: told federal investigators he relayed the concerns to Cheryl Mills
column5: then Clinton's chief of staff.Mills
column6: whose lawyer did not respond to requests for comment
column7: has previously testified under oath she could not recall anyone alerting her to potential problems with Clinton's email arrangement.The episode had not been disclosed until the Federal Bureau of Investigation released on Friday night nearly 200 pages of additional records from its year-long investigation into the handling of classified government documents by Clinton and her staff via an unauthorized email server in the basement of her New York home.Clinton has said the decision to use a private email system was a mistake
column8: but the controversy has dogged her campaign as the Democratic candidate for the presidency and raised public doubts about her trustworthiness
column9: public opinion polls show. Republicans have criticized her for putting national security at risk.The FBI closed the year-long investigation in July
column11: although FBI Director James Comey said Clinton and her staff had been ""extremely careless"" in handling classified government secrets.

column1: Pagliano has declined to answer questions by Republican lawmakers about his work on Clinton's server
column2: but spoke to federal investigators after securing a form of immunity from prosecution.He told investigators two colleagues from the technology office approached him with concerns during Clinton's first year after learning about the email system. One said it could lead to a ""federal records retention issue
column3: Pagliano told investigators
column4: and urged him to raise the concern with Clinton's ""inner circle.""A colleague also warned Pagliano ""he wouldn't be surprised"" if classified information was being sent through Clinton's unsecure system
column5: Pagliano told the FBI.The newly released interview summaries from the FBI investigation show government employees undercutting other aspects of the public accounts given by Clinton and senior State officials.

column1: A State Department employee
column2: whose name was redacted
column3: told investigators they believed senior department officials interfered with the screening of Clinton's emails for public release last year in a way that helped Clinton. The employee
column4: who worked on the screening process
column5: said there was pressure to obscure the fact they were finding classified information in the messages. John Kirby
column6: a State Department spokesman
column7: said in a statement the department ""strongly disputes"" the claim of interference. Clinton repeatedly said last year she never sent or received classified information
column8: but now says she did not do so knowingly since the release of the FBI findings.The employee also said the Defense Department told the State Department last year it had found about 1
column9: 000 emails between Clinton and David Petraeus in its records from his time as the director of the United States Central Command.

column1: The State Department has said that Clinton did not include any of her emails with Petraeus when her lawyers screened and returned what they said were all her work emails in 2014. A single conversation of about 10 emails later emerged last year after the Defense Department provided it.Spokesmen for Clinton have declined to discuss the omission
column2: and did not respond to questions about the new interview summaries.Kirby
column3: the department spokesman
column4: said he could not ""speculate"" whether the Defense Department had found more than just a single conversation between Clinton and Petraeus. ""We can only speak to the records in our possession
column5: he said. (Reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by John Whitesides and Mary Milliken)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN11U0JA	N.Y. Times endorses Clinton in White House race	"
By John Whitesides
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The New York Times endorsed Democrat Hillary Clinton for the White House on Saturday
column2: saying she was more qualified than Republican presidential rival Donald Trump to handle the challenges facing the United States.The newspaper described Clinton as ""one of the most tenacious politicians of her generation"" and said she had displayed a command of policy and diplomatic nuance while building a reputation for grit and bipartisan cooperation.""A lifetime's commitment to solving problems in the real world qualifies Hillary Clinton for this job
column3: and the country should put her to work
column4: the Times said of the former secretary of state and U.S. senator from New York.Clinton will face off against Trump on Monday night in the first of three presidential debates
column5: with opinion polls showing her once sizable lead over the New York businessman narrowing amid continued public doubts about her trustworthiness.The Times said Clinton's mistakes had distorted perceptions of her character
column6: but praised her work restoring U.S. credibility in foreign affairs as secretary of state and on behalf of children
column7: women and families throughout her career.

column1: Mrs. Clinton has shown herself to be a realist who believes America cannot simply withdraw behind oceans and walls
column2: but must engage confidently in the world to protect its interests and be true to its values
column3: the newspaper said.It said Clinton's decision to use a private email server for government work as secretary of state deserved the scrutiny it has received in the campaign
column4: but considered alongside the real challenges facing the United States it ""looks like a matter for the help desk.""Viewed against those challenges
column5: Trump ""shrinks to his true small-screen
column6: reality-show proportions
column8: promising another editorial on Monday explaining ""why we believe Mr. Trump to be the worst nominee put forward by a major party in modern American history.""

column1: The endorsement from the Times editorial board is no surprise. The last Republican the Times backed for the White House was President Dwight Eisenhower in 1956. But several newspapers with more conservative editorial boards
column2: including the Dallas Morning News and Cincinnati Enquirer
column3: also have recently endorsed Clinton.The Times said Clinton's best argument for the White House was her ability to rise to the challenges facing the country.

column1: The 2016 campaign has brought to the surface the despair and rage of poor and middle-class Americans"" facing the burdens of recession
column2: technological change
column3: foreign competition and war
column4: it said.""Over 40 years in public life
column5: Hillary Clinton has studied these forces and weighed responses to these problems. Our endorsement is rooted in respect for her intellect
column6: experience
column7: toughness and courage over a career of almost continuous public service
column8: often as the first or only woman in the arena
column9: the newspaper said. (Writing by John Whitesides; Editing by Franklin Paul)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ohio-idUSKCN11T2KN	Ohio system of purging inactive voters not legal: court	"
By Kim Palmer
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Ohio's practice of rescinding voter registrations from people who fail to cast ballots is illegal
column2: a court ruled on Friday
column3: the latest legal decision affecting voting rights ahead of the U.S. presidential election on Nov. 8. The decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati reversed an earlier ruling by a federal judge in June and could lead to the reinstatement of thousands of voters in the politically crucial swing state of Ohio.""We don't believe that any voters should be removed from the rolls simply because they haven't voted in a few elections
column4: said Mike Brickner
column5: senior policy director at the American Civil Liberties Union
column6: which brought a lawsuit against the practice along with other advocates.Voting rights cases have become pivotal battlegrounds in the lead-up to the hotly contested presidential vote between Democratic party candidate Hillary Clinton and her Republican counterpart Donald Trump. The ACLU and others have challenged laws in Wisconsin
column8: North Carolina over voting rights issues. On Friday Texas asked the U.S. Supreme Court to reinstate a law requiring authorized identification to be presented before a citizen may vote.

column1: At issue in the Ohio case is a policy of purging voters who  fail to cast ballots over a six-year period and do not respond to a letter from the state asking if they have moved.        A Reuters analysis showed that at least 144
column2: 000 voters had been removed from Ohio's rolls since the last presidential election.

column1: In their lawsuit
column2: the ACLU and other plaintiffs argued that the process violates federal voting rights law
column3: which prohibits removing voters from the rolls simply because they have been inactive.In June
column4: a federal judge disagreed
column5: ruling that an exception in the law protected Ohio's practice. But the appellate court said on Friday that because the removal process was triggered solely by someone's failure to vote
column6: it was not legal.The appeals court sent the case back to U.S. District Judge George C. Smith to consider possible remedies
column7: including reinstating all voters removed under the process.

column1: Ohio Secretary of State Jon Husted
column2: a Republican
column3: said the state would appeal if Smith orders all of the purged voters to be reinstated
column4: arguing that would open the state to potential fraud by people impersonating voters who have died or moved away.""This ruling overturns 20 years of Ohio law and practice
column5: which has been carried out by the last four Secretaries of State
column6: both Democrat and Republican
column7: Husted said.     (Editing by Sharon Bernstein and Alan Crosby)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN11T2L1	'Bridgegate' trial star witness describes favors for endorsements	"
By Hilary Russ
| NEWARK
column2: N.J.

column1: NEWARK
column2: N.J. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's office turned a regional transportation agency into a ""goodie bag"" from which to dole out favors and funds to Democrats who might endorse the Republican during his 2013 re-election campaign
column3: according to prosecutors' star witness in the so-called Bridgegate trial on Friday.David Wildstein
column4: a former executive at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey who pleaded guilty and is testifying for the prosecution
column5: described how requests from state officials went first to a top Christie aide for approval - for everything from patronage jobs at the agency to tours of the World Trade Center site
column6: which the Port Authority owns.The aide
column7: Christie's then-deputy chief of staff Bridget Anne Kelly
column9: the former deputy executive director of the Port Authority
column10: are on trial for wire fraud and civil rights deprivation.Kelly and Baroni are accused of arranging in September 2013 to close traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in order to cause gridlock in Fort Lee
column12: as retribution after the municipality's Democratic mayor did not endorse Christie's successful re-election bid.The scandal helped torpedo Christie's bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

column1: At the start of the trial
column2: federal prosecutors claimed for the first time that Christie knew his two close associates were involved in the shutdown.Christie has denied any knowledge of the plot.Wildstein said the ""goodie bag"" scheme allowed Christie's office to take credit for items given by the Port Authority
column3: a bi-state agency run jointly with New York.

column1: That was the system that was established. All use of Port Authority resources had to be approved by the governor's office
column2: Wildstein
column4: testified. ""The governor's office was always to be the deliverer of good news.""In one case
column5: Wildstein had the 100 flags flown over the World Trade Center site on the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11  attacks shipped to the governor's office after the ceremony to be distributed to local officials as it saw fit.The office considered whether officials were willing to endorse Christie when deciding how to hand out the flags
column6: surplus equipment

column1: Baroni
column2: whom Wildstein described as ""one of the closest friends I've ever had
column3: hired Wildstein to be the ""bad cop"" in pushing Christie's agenda at the authority
column4: Wildstein said.""If it was good for Christie then it was good for us
column5: Wildstein said.Wildstein's testimony continues on Monday. (Editing by Matthew Lewis)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-charlotte-idUSKCN11U01N	Hillary Clinton postpones trip to Charlotte -campaign statement	"
WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has postponed a trip planned for Sunday to Charlotte
column2: North Carolina
column3: which has seen sometimes violent protests after a black man was killed by police earlier this week.""Hillary is grateful for
column4: and intends to honor
column5: the invitation from faith leaders to visit with the Charlotte community
column6: her campaign said in a statement on Friday.

column1: After further discussion with community leaders
column2: we have decided to postpone Sunday's trip as to not impact the city's resources
column3: it said

column1: (Reporting by Eric Beech; Editing by Sandra Maler)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-obama-idUSKCN11T2NQ	As Syria cease-fire fails
column2: Obama may leave successor 'problem from hell'	"

column1: By Jonathan Landay and Matt Spetalnick
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The United States was relegated to the sidelines of the Syrian war on Friday as an all-out assault by Syrian government and Russian forces on opposition-held Aleppo threatened to unleash a new refugee wave and drive U.S.-backed rebels into the ranks of al Qaeda's Syrian branch
column2: U.S. officials and experts said.Moscow's direct participation in the offensive left fading hope for U.S.-Russian peace efforts
column3: raising the likelihood that U.S. President Barack Obama's successor will inherit a worsening conflict.Entering its sixth year
column4: the Syrian civil war already has left some 250
column5: 000 people dead
column6: uprooted more than 11 million and provided a base for Islamic State to launch and inspire attacks in the West.""For the next president on Day One
column7: this becomes the problem from hell
column9: a former Obama adviser on Syria who is now at the Atlantic Council think tank. ""It's a problem that's going to persist in one way or another throughout the first term of the next president and probably beyond.""A U.S. official suggested White House plans to keep Syrian chaos under control as Obama leaves office have been upended.""It was hoped that they could turn over a simmering mess to the next president
column10: said a U.S. official. ""But what happened was that the simmering mess blew up and now they are going to have to figure out what to do.""U.S. officials
column13: long-range artillery and special forces advisers were directly participating with Syrian government forces in the drive to conquer eastern Aleppo
column14: the largest urban stronghold of the U.S.-backed moderate opposition.Shiite militiamen from Lebanon
column15: Iraq and Afghanistan also were involved in the assault on the devastated enclave
column17: 000 civilians were suffering the most intense airstrikes of the war
column18: they said.""The Russians are actively participating in the current offensive in Aleppo
column19: said one U.S. official. ""It appears to be a no-holds barred attempt to crush the opposition."" Russian aircraft were flying sorties at the same rate - about 40 per day - as they were before Washington and Moscow negotiated a failed ceasefire between the Syria government and opposition forces in February

column1: Some U.S. intelligence officials believe that Russian President Vladimir Putin is taking advantage of Obama's refusal to intervene militarily in Syria and his lame duck status to seize as much territory as possible before the new U.S. president takes office.These officials argue that Russia has not sincerely engaged in peace-making efforts and that Putin aims to weaken the opposition as rapidly as possible
column2: a goal in which he is gradually succeeding.Damascus announced the offensive on Thursday as Secretary of State John Kerry and Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov failed to salvage a ceasefire that collapsed on Monday. The ceasefire was supposed to lead to U.S.-Russian cooperation on airstrikes against Islamic State and al Qaeda's Syrian affiliate
column3: formerly known as the Nusra Front.OBAMA'S OPTIONS

column1: What course Obama will now take remained unclear.""There doesn't seem to be a Plan B right now
column2: Hof said.Obama has sought to restrict U.S. involvement in Syria
column3: repeatedly rejecting proposals by advisers for actions such as establishing a no-fly zone or arming the moderate opposition fighting to topple President Bashar Assad.""One of the things that haunts me the most was our failure to ask ourselves about the consequences of inaction
column4: said one former senior official involved in Syria policy. ""We were always focused on the consequences of action ... But we should have also considered how doing nothing for several years might have an impact on U.S. credibility and the conflict more broadly.""Obama has limited the U.S. role to supporting groups fighting Islamic State in northeastern Syria. He has pursued  talks with Russia
column5: which intervened on Assad's behalf in September 2015
column6: on a peace accord between U.S.-backed moderate rebels and Damascus.

column1: Obama
column2: however
column3: no longer can count on securing a ceasefire that will keep a lid on the crisis until his successor is sworn-in on Jan. 20
column4: experts said.Charles Lister of the Middle East Institute think tank said he doubted that Obama would adopt a more robust policy.""Given the posture the Obama administration has developed with regards to how it faces the war in Syria
column5: I don't see it shifting the strategy
column6: he said. ""That would be the most extraordinary foreign policy shift in the last eight years.""Obama
column8: faces the prospect of a deepening humanitarian disaster
column9: officials and experts said.The fall of Aleppo could unleash a new wave of migrants fleeing toward Europe
column10: which has been struggling since last year to accommodate more than 1 million refugees.Moreover
column12: dismayed over what they saw as Obama's abandonment of Aleppo
column13: could begin joining al Qaeda's Syrian branch. It is widely regarded as the most effective opposition group and has vehemently rejected a negotiated settlement with Assad
column15: who maintains contacts with rebels inside Syria
column16: said opposition leaders are growing disillusioned with U.S. efforts to negotiate a diplomatic solution with Assad's main military backer.""Things are deteriorating so quickly now. The U.S. is losing leverage on the ground every week
column17: he said.      (Additional reporting by Phil Stewart and David Rohde. Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"
